items.message: River levels remain high but are currently falling on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Levels are expected to rise again in response to this mornings rainfall peaking in the early evening today. Flooding is expected to affect locations near these watercourses, with low lying land expected to be most affected. Flooding is possible at the road at Reybridge during today, Sunday (10/12/2023). We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue or update this alert and issue warnings if necessary. We are monitoring defences and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Mersey catchment including areas near Bramhall, Stockport, Sale, Altrincham and Urmston

floodArea.county: Cheshire East, Manchester, Salford, Stockport, Tameside, Trafford, Warrington

items.message:
Further rainfall is forecast across the Middle Mersey catchment throughout Sunday 10/12/2023 into the early hours of Monday morning. The heaviest of the rain will occur early this evening from around 5pm until around 2am on Monday 11/12/23. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible from around 1am on 11/12/23. There will be flooding on Ford Lane from around 1am on 11/12/23 until around midday on the 11/12/23.
River levels will remaining high on the River Mersey until around midday on 11/12/23.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around Micker, Cringle, Sinderland and Poynton Brooks and their tributaries.
Our duty officer are closely monitoring the situation and will update you when the forecast changes. Our operational teams are out clearing debris screens to minimise potential blockages and flow restriction.
This message will be updated on 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Sunday 10th December 2023. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for scattered showers for the next few days.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Monday 11th December, or as the situation changes.

The River Lavant is high following a wet autumn, but currently stable. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields between West Dean and Westhampnett. Small amounts of flood water might affect parts of Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green in East Lavant. At The Sadlers in Westhampnett, the river will be about 30cm from the top of the bank. River flooding should not affect Chichester City Centre. Showers midday Sunday 10/12/2023 will cause river levels to rise a couple of centimetres again, through Sunday afternoon, but should not rise as high as Saturday. Periods of heavy rain Tuesday 12/12/2023 could potentially cause some minor flood impacts, possibly approaching properties. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are operating the River Lavant Flood Alleviation Scheme to reduce the flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 11/12/2023.

River levels are rising at the Sandhurst river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. Predicted peaks:- Mythe 4.1m to 4.4m Wednesday afternoon 13/12/2023, Haw Bridge 5.0m to 5.2m Thursday morning 14/12/2023, Sandhurst 3.5m to 3.9m Friday morning 15/12/2023, Gloucester 3.3m to 3.6m Friday morning 15/12/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Pillings Lock and Kegworth river gauges as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the past several days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road and Sileby Mill road, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes.   Areas also at risk include low-lying agricultural land and roads around Loughborough, Zouch, Kegworth, Ratcliffe on Soar, Meadow Lane at Loughborough and the access road from Ratcliffe on Soar to Redhill Marina.   

River levels are steady but could rise overnight into Monday 11/12/23.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
  
This message will be updated by 09:00, Monday 11/12/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels on the Upper River Aire have been steadily falling through today, 10/12/2023. Due to further rain expected this evening and into the early hours of Monday morning, levels are expected to increase once again overnight. With only limited capacity available in Cononley washlands, levels are likely to be particularly high in the Kildwick area going into Monday morning, but should fall later in the day. Therefore, this Flood Alert remains in force. Areas most at risk include locations near the River Aire, Eller Beck and Waller Hill Beck, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the River Aire from Gargrave to Stockbridge, including Eshton Beck, Eller Beck and Silsden Beck. There remains a risk of flooding of low lying land and minor roads. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 08:45 AM on 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Levels remain high at the Lodore gauge that monitors Derwent Water lake level due to recent rainfall.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.

We continue to monitor the rainfall, river and lake levels and are checking for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 11/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise at the Bridgnorth, Buildwas, Crew Green, Montford and Welshbridge river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth and access to properties along Riverside in Bridgnorth.
Predicted Peaks:-
Crew Green 5.8m to 6.0m this morning, Sunday 10/12/23.
Montford, 5.2m to 5.6m, and Buildwas, 4.1m to 4.7m, Monday afternoon 11/12/23.
Welshbridge, 2.9m to 3.4m, and Bridgnorth, 3.2m to 3.8m, Tuesday morning 12/12/23.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. Frankwell phase 1 barriers are being deployed today, Sunday 10/12/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00am Monday 11/12/23, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.48m and is slowly falling. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor is 6.61m and is slowly rising. For up-to-date water levels visit the gauge section of our website (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/station/3064). The rainfall during Sunday morning will pass out of the area around lunchtime leaving a mostly dry afternoon and evening. The risk of flooding remains possible over the next few days. We continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels closely, and our staff are checking flood defences and pumps. We will operate the pumps at Stanmoor, Northmoor, Saltmoor and Currymoor stations when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used to evacuate water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence. Consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Do not attempt to drive, walk or cycle through flood water. This message will be updated by midday on Monday, 11th December, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely to continue today, Sunday 10th December and overnight. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message tomorrow morning, Monday 11th December.

The Western Rother is high in Fittleworth, following 20mm of rain Saturday. The data shows that the river at Fittleworth is now falling, but flood water will continue to be close to Fittleworth Mill, throughout Sunday. It is possible the Western Rother could still rise a few centimetres at Fittleworth on Sunday. At Lodsbridge near Selham the Western Rother is now falling, and flood impacts should slowly ease, although the river is unlikely to fall nearer to normal until Monday. Between Liss and Midhurst river levels are already near normal. Showers midday Sunday 10/12/2023 could slow the Western Rother's fall, or cause a small river rise. Another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday 12/12/2023, which could see flood risk return. Water levels will remain sensitive to additional rainfall over the next few weeks. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 11/12/2023.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high but now stable, following Saturday's rain. Flood water will continue to affect land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre, parts of the car park at Tesco on Shripney Road, as well as fields near Shripney Lane. In Barnham, river levels are slowly falling and any minor flood impacts will reduce. Showers midday Sunday 10/12/2023 will cause river levels to rise a couple of centimetres again, through Sunday afternoon. Rain on Tuesday 12/12/2023 might cause river levels in Bersted to rise by a further 10cm. Flood water will continue to affect caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre, and from Tuesday 12/12/2023 might approach properties on Durban Road, Bersted. Water levels will remain sensitive to any additional rain in December. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barnham, if you have them. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 11/12/2023.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Sunday 10th December and for the next few days. Water levels continue to remain high in this area. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Monday 11th December, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
A flood alert has been issued. A flood alert has been issued. River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon due to heavy rainfall on Thursday. We are due further rain on Saturday.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.
Flooding is possible in tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch..
Further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout tomorrow.
River levels are rising steadily at the Ringwood Old Cottage gauge.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: Groundwater levels at all sites in West Dorset have continued to rise throughout the day. It is likely that some roads will be flooded in the South Winterbourne, Hooke, Sydling and Cerne Valleys. Householders with pumps and other property level resilience measures should deploy them now. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can damage adjacent property and may put your own and emergency responders lives at risk. This message will be updated tomorrow, Sunday the 10th Decemberv

River levels are remaining high on the River Piddle following the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.  Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by  04:00 PM on 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Willington Cableway river gauge and rising on the Shardlow river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Ingleby, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Areas also at risk include the B5008 at Willington, the access frontage at Swarkestone, the A5132 between Willington and Barrow, and Meadow Lane.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated this morning, 11/12/23, or as the situation changes.

We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message tomorrow morning, Monday 11th December.

Flooding remains possible at properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Our riverside defences remain in place. The Foss Barrier is in operation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 12:00pm on Monday 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely to continue today, Sunday 10th December and overnight. River levels are expected to continue to rise following recent rainfall.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message tomorrow morning, Monday 11th December.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is very high. At Alverstone the level is falling, at Sandown the level is now stable. Today (Sunday 10/12/23), a continuation of flooding affecting land, access and cycle tracks, gardens and roads (Golf Links and Moreton Common Road) is expected. The river will remain bankfull at Sandown Road Bridge. From 10:00 to 14:00 showers are forecast with up to 7mm expected. Whilst this is only a small amount of rain, the river will be very responsive, and so by lunchtime, it is likely that it will begin to rise again. Any increase in level should be relatively minor and it is unlikely to cause additional flooding to property. The river however, will remain very high for the next 12 hours. We have operated Bembridge sluice. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding can continue to operate.  This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Monday 11/12/23.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to rainfall over the past few weeks and remain high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming weeks. 

The groundwater level at Draycot Foliat is higher than normal for this time of year and is currently very slowly rising.  The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding.  Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 15/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.74m, and is currently falling by 20 mm per hour. The drain level is 8.59m and is stable. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35m. We are currently unable to pump at Huish Episcopi pumping station due to the high river level, but will commence as soon as river levels allow. The rainfall during Sunday morning is forecast to pass out of the area around lunchtime, leaving a mostly dry afternoon and evening. The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain high throughout this unsettled period. The situation is being continually monitored and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures. This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on Monday 11th December, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.48m and is slowly falling. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor is 6.61m and is slowly rising. For up-to-date water levels visit the gauge section of our website (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/station/3064). The rainfall during Sunday morning will pass out of the area around lunchtime, leaving a mostly dry afternoon and evening. The risk of flooding remains possible over the next few days. We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely, and our staff are checking flood defences and pumps. We will operate the pumps at Stanmoor, Northmoor, Saltmoor and Currymoor stations when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is also being used to evacuate water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence. Consider weather conditions, local water levels, and your flood plan if you have one. Do not attempt to drive, walk or cycle through flood water. This message will be updated by 12 PM on Monday, 11th December, or as the situation changes.

The river levels in the River Parrett remain high at Langport and on the moor at Westover Pumping station. The River Yeo at Ilchester and Pen Mill have now fallen but flood water remains on large areas of the Somerset Levels and Moors, especially around Mulchelney. 
Areas most at risk include the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road, and the road at the south end of Westover Trading Estate. Properties at Westover Trading Estate at Langport are also at risk.
 The rainfall during Sunday morning will pass out of the area around lunchtime leaving a mostly dry afternoon and evening.  The risk of flooding remains possible over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation closely, as well as checking flood banks, pumps and weed screens. Please consider local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk, cycle, or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 15:00 on Monday 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

Locations near The Vatch and Libbys Drive may start to see some impacts. Flood water could be deep and fast flowing, and therefore pose a risk to life. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to fall but then rise again in the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and or Local Authorities. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Groundwater in Hambledon is high. Since Tuesday 05/12/2023, the level at our borehole at Whitedale Farm has fallen by 64cm. In the last 48 hours, 22mm of rain has been recorded at Worlds End. On Saturday 09/12/2023, another 15-25mm of rain will affect East Hampshire. From Sunday 10/12/2023 to Tuesday 12/12/2023, showery rain is forecast. In the next couple of days, groundwater levels are expected to continue rising again. Water levels in cellars will become deeper, and it is possible that more properties on West Street will experience cellar flooding by the end of next week. Long range forecasting is difficult, but there is currently an indication that more settled weather is possible from Wednesday 13/12/2023 until Sunday 17/12/2023. Groundwater levels in Hambledon are expected to continue rising into the week beginning 18/12/2023. We are liaising with the Hambledon Flood Action Group. Please remove any valuables from cellars, and if you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Thursday 14/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: Groundwater levels in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle have remained high for the last 7 days and the Idsworth Lavant is flowing throughout all villages. Today (07/12/2023), heavy rain is forecast in Hampshire with 15 to 40mm possible. On Saturday 09/12/2023, up to 25mm of rain is possible. Groundwater levels are now expected to rise throughout the next week and flow in the Idsworth Lavant will increase. Pumps which prevent water from entering property will be required for a small number of properties. During heavier rain events, surface water could flood property. If heavy rainfall continues affecting the area in December, the Chalton Lavant could begin to flow in the next couple of weeks, causing deep road flooding and further property impacts. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Thursday 14/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.

The groundwater level at Longacre is higher than normal for this time of year but is currently very slowly declining. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and groundwater levels and may start to rise again if there is further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 15/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are high on the Upper River Frome at the Stinsford river gauge and may rise in response to the rainfall this morning, Sunday 10/12/23..  High groundwater levels are adding to the river levels and we expect flooding to affect areas in Higher Frome Vauchurch, Frome Vauchurch, Cruxton, Notton. Frampton, Grimstone, Muckleford, Stratton, Bradford Peverell, Wrackleford, Charminster, Frome Whitfield, Wolfeton, Lower Burton and Cokers Frome. items.description: River Brue and Glastonbury Millstream from Lovington to Highbridge, low lying properties
items.message: The forecast for today, Sunday, 10/12/2023 is for isolated showers, heavy at times, during the morning before drier weather during the afternoon and overnight.

River levels are rising at the Hamerton gauge following the rainfall this morning.  It is expected that levels will peak here in the next few hours. The forecast is for no significant rainfall tomorrow, 11/12/23, however rain is possible on Tuesday. This further rain could see river levels begin to rise again as the catchment is saturated. Flooding is possible over night today. Areas most at risk are around Alconbury Brook at Hamerton, The Alconburys, Little Stukeley and Brampton. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don’t put yourself in unnecessary danger. Move parked cars out of flood risk areas, and avoid walking or driving through flood water. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, 11/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and the Cadnam River at Cadnam, remains higher than normal, but has lowered following the heavy rainfall recorded yesterday (Saturday 9/12/23). Residual flood impacts to land, roads and gardens is expected to continue over the next 3 to 4 days. Showers are forecast tomorrow (11/12/23) but the volume of rain should be small (similar to today). The river may rise a little, but any associated impacts will be minor. On Tuesday (12/12/23) heavier rain is forecast with up to 20mm expected. If this volume of rain affects the river then more significant flooding will impact lands, roads and gardens. It may also impact property. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property can continue to operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 12/12/23.

The Combe Haven through Bulverhythe is high and will rise 20cm each high tide. Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe will remain affected by flood water. The Powdermill Stream through Crowhurst has fallen significantly, following Saturday's rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields and roads in Crowhurst should continue to ease while the river falls Sunday. Showers midday Sunday could cause a brief river rise. Rivers in Crowhurst should temporarily return nearer to normal by Monday. However, another 10-20mm of rain on Tuesday 12/12/2023 could increase flood risk again, in both Crowhurst and Bulverhythe. In Bulverhythe river levels could remain higher than normal all week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 11/12/2023.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but steady on the Cranleigh Waters as a result of a period of sustained rain. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is possible this evening 10/12/23, especially in the Cranleigh area.
The forecast is for it to be dry tomorrow. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 11/12/23 or if the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River through Alfriston and the Bull River through Hellingly are high but now slowly falling following Saturday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Flood water will also continue to affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Showers midday Sunday could cause another brief river rise, but should not cause further property flooding. Rivers in Hellingly should temporarily return nearer to normal by Monday. In Alfriston, the Cuckmere could remain high all week. Another 10-20mm of rain on Tuesday 12/12/2023 could increase flood risk again. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 11/12/2023.

items.message: The risk of flooding from the rivers in the South Devon Rivers area has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels are falling at the Wingfield Park river gauge, but the risk of flooding to roads and farmland continues. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads along the River Amber around Ambergate. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 04:30pm, 10/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels were falling but are beginning to rise following this mornings, 10/12/23, rainfall. The forecast is for no significant rainfall tomorrow, 11/12/23, however rain is possible on Tuesday. This further rain could see river levels begin to rise again as the catchment is saturated. Flooding may be possible following today's rainfall. Areas most at risk are around the River Tove between Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook and the Stoke Bruerne Marina. Move cars out of this flood risk area. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation and will provide further updates as the situation changes. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, 11/12/2023.

The River Ouse is high near Barcombe but slowly falling, following Saturday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens, the Anchor Inn, Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge, and Barcombe Mills Road, while the river levels fall. The river has already fallen nearer to normal at Ardingly and near Lindfield. Showers midday Sunday could slow the river's fall or generate a small river rise. The River Ouse should temporarily return nearer to normal by Monday. However, another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday 12/12/2023, which could see flood risk return. Some roads may become impassable, including Barcombe Mills Road, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 11/12/2023.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high and rising slightly on the River Windrush. Therefore, the risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains, especially in the Newbridge area. The weather forecast is for it to be mostly dry with the chance of showers this evening  and overnight, and Monday is forecast to be mostly dry. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall for the next few days.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high, but now slowly falling, following Saturday's rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens, rural roads including Willows Car Park and North Street, and properties including The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, and River Lane, Alfriston. A band of light rain midday Sunday might delay the fall of the Cuckmere river, but water levels should be significantly lower by Sunday evening, and will continue to fall Monday. However, another 20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday, which could cause flood risk to return. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if properties are expected to flood again.

River levels on the Lower River Rother have fallen after last nights rain, but are expected to increase once again following another band of rain forecast for tonight, 10/12/2023.  Despite this, we currently expect to see lower levels than those reached last night, 9/12/2023.  Therefore, this Flood Alert remains in force. Areas most at risk include the River Rother and its tributaries from Renishaw to Rotherham
Levels are expected to rise again from around 09:00 PM tonight, 10/12/2023, with a peak in Killamarsh around 03:00 to 05:00 AM on Monday morning. We will continue to monitor rainfall and river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 08:10 AM on 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message: A flood warning has been issued. River levels are expected to rise in the Lower Stour overnight on Saturday and into Sunday following Friday’s overnight rainfall and will remain high on the Lower Dorset Stour from Sturminster Marshall to Christchurch. Flooding is expected and areas at risk include the farms at Sturminster Marshall, Cowgrove, Shops in Wimborne, Mill Street in Corfe Mullen, Bridge House Hotel in Ferndown, Brecon Close, Ringwood Road, Throop Road in Bournemouth, Barrack Road and Willow Way in Christchurch. This means properties are at risk of flooding. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Flooding to roads and low lying land is possible and conditions can apply one to two hours either side of high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff will be closing flood gates if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: October and November 2023 have been exceptionally wet. Groundwater is high, within a metre of the surface at East Dean, and rising 10cm each day. 15-30mm of rain is forecast Thursday afternoon 07/12/2023. From 09/12/2023 minor groundwater flood impacts are possible, with springs appearing, water flowing on roads, water in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. A further 20mm of rain is possible Saturday 09/12/2023. Only small amounts of rain are currently forecast Friday, Sunday and next week. Groundwater is expected to continue rising until 15/12/2023 at Chilgrove and until the New Year at East Dean. If the second half of December is dry, groundwater flood impacts might ease in January. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 13/12/2023.

items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.74m, and is currently falling by 20 mm per hour. The drain level is 8.59m and is stable. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35m. We are currently unable to pump at Huish Episcopi pumping station due to the high river level, but will commence as soon as river levels allow. The rainfall during Sunday morning is forecast to pass out of the area around lunchtime, leaving a mostly dry afternoon and evening. The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain high throughout this unsettled period. The situation is being continually monitored and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures. items.message: Groundwater levels at the Doles Ash borehole are still rising. Some property flooding as well as disruption to the road and sewer networks is expected. Home owners with property level resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should check that they are in place and working properly. Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave from vehicles can damage adjacent properties. Stay out of flood water which is hazardous to you and emergency service staff who may have to rescue you. This message will be updated tomorrow, Sunday the 10th December

The River Ems is high following a wet autumn, but currently stable. Only minimal flood impacts are currently expected, affecting small areas of fields, rural roads and gardens in Westbourne and Emsworth. Showers midday Sunday 10/12/2023 will cause river levels to rise a couple of centimetres again through Sunday afternoon, but should not rise as high as Saturday. Periods of heavy rain Tuesday 12/12/2023 could potentially cause the River Ems to rise higher and generate some minor flood impacts, possibly approaching properties. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Westbourne and Emsworth, if you have them. We are operating our structure at Constant Springs and clearing grilles to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 11/12/2023.

The water level in the upper River Meon remains high but stable following months of prolonged wet weather and heavy rainfall recorded yesterday (Saturday 9/12/23). Today (Sunday 10/12/23) and tomorrow (Monday 11/12/23) out of bank flooding will affect low lying land and roads throughout East and West Meon, Exton and Wickham. In central Wickham, the river will be deep and fast flowing. Showers are forecast tomorrow (11/12/23) but the volume of rain should be small (similar to today). The river should remain stable or may even lower a little. On Tuesday (12/12/23) heavier rain is forecast with up to 20mm expected. If this volume of rain affects the river then more significant flooding will impact lands, roads, gardens and public spaces. Property flooding directly from the river is not currently expected. Our operational staff will keep the river clear of reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 12/12/23.

Residents are urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings.

items.message:
River levels have now fallen following heavy rainfall yesterday and today, Sunday 10th December. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. There is no further rainfall forecast this evening or tomorrow, Monday 11th December. 

We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and clearing blockages in rivers where necessary. 

We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Piddle Valley
items.message: Groundwater Levels at the Doles Ash borehole have risen steeply following several days intense rainfall. Homeowners with property level resilience measures, such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers should put them in place and check that they are working correctly. Do not drive through flood water as the bow wave can seriously damage adjacent properties. Food water is dangerous - entering it can put your life and that of emergency responders at risk. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message tomorrow, Sunday the 10th December. In an emergency contact Dorset Council on 01305 221000.

The water level in the lower River Meon at Titchfield remains high but stable following months of prolonged wet weather and heavy rainfall recorded on Saturday (09/12/23). Today (Sunday 10/12/23) and tomorrow (Monday 11/12/23) out of bank flooding will impact fields at Titchfield Hill with high water levels at Titchfield Mill, Bridge Cottage and the Tanneries Industrial Estate. Showers are forecast tomorrow (11/12/23) but the volume of rain should be small (similar to today). The river should remain stable and may even lower a little. On Tuesday (12/12/23) heavier rain is forecast with up to 20mm expected. If this volume of rain affects the river then the level will rise and deeper flood water will affect the area. Low lying land will remain flooded for at least the next 2 weeks. Property flooding directly from the river is not currently expected. Our operational staff will keep the river clear of reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 12/12/23.

items.description: Whitwell, Wroxall, Langbridge, Alverstone on the Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar remains very high, but at Langbridge and Alverstone, it is now slowly falling. Today (Sunday 10/12/23), a continuation of flooding affecting land, the access track to Horringford, cycle tracks and footpaths, gardens and roads (Golf Links) is expected. From 10:00 to 14:00, showers are forecast with up to 7mm expected. Whilst this is only a small amount of rain, the river will be very responsive, and so by lunchtime, it is likely that it will begin to rise again. Any increase in level should be relatively minor, and it is unlikely to cause additional flooding to property. The river may however, be held at bankfull at Alverstone Road Bridge for longer than expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding can continue to operate. If recorded rainfall totals remain low today, then we may remove this flood warning later this evening. If not, the message will be updated by 10:00 on Monday 11/12/23.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Sunday 10th December 2023. The forecast is for scattered showers for the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Monday 11th December, or as the situation changes.

The early morning high tide level on Monday 11/12/2023, at 4.35am is expected to be higher than normal. This is due to the unsettled weather with westerly force 7 winds and has the potential for large waves. There may be some spray overtopping, so take care if you are near the coast.
Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point, including Porlock Weir harbourside properties in particular.
Flooding is possible two hours each side of high tide.
No further impacts are expected beyond this, so we expect to remove the flood alert later on 11/12/2023."

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: October and November 2023 have been exceptionally wet. Nearly a month's rainfall (80mm) has been recorded this week. Groundwater is high, close to the surface, and rising. From 13/12/2023 minor groundwater flood impacts are possible, with springs and minor flooding affecting fields, the village green at Stoughton, and rural roads including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden and also between Cooks Lane and The Barley Mow, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane, in Walderton. Showers are forecast Sunday, Monday and Wednesday, with a further 25mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday 12/12/2023. Groundwater is expected to continue rising until at least 17/12/2023. If dry weather returns, groundwater flood impacts might ease in January 2024. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall, with flood risk possible over the winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 15/12/2023

Last night’s rain has cleared the catchment and levels have peaked on Glusburn Beck and have fallen below levels of concern. There are further bands of rain forecast mid-morning and this evening, Sunday 10/12/2023, and we will continue to monitor the forecast the re-issue this alert if necessary. Areas most at risk include the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river from the A63 near Selby to the Yokefleet, Blacktoft and Faxfleet areas. Further rain is forecast overnight and into Monday. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00am on Monday 11/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Aire at Allerton Ings, Barnsdale Road and Properties
items.message: River levels have been steadily falling at Castleford through today, and stopped spilling into Allerton Ings this morning, 10/12/2023. Due to further rain expected this evening and into the early hours of Monday morning, levels are expected to increase once again overnight, creating a second peak on Monday morning. There is potential for this to lead to further spilling into Allerton Ings on Monday, depending on whether the heavier areas of rain affect the Aire catchment. Areas most at risk are low-lying land, the A656 Barnsdale Road and adjacent properties. Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. We will continue to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 06:00 AM on 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message:
River levels have been rising through today as a result of yesterday's persistent heavy rainfall. Washlands between Temple Hirst and Gowdall have been filling through the day, resulting in flooding of farmland and low-lying roads.  Further rainfall is expected this evening, 10/12/2023, into the early hours of Monday morning. As a result of this and further unsettled weather, levels are likely to remain high through Monday and well into the new week.
Tides will be steadily rising until Friday. This series of small spring tides is likely to slow the rate at which water in the Tidal Aire catchment can drain away through the week. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid walking around washlands, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by, 08:40 AM on 11/12/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Sunday 10th December 2023. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for scattered showers for the next few days.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Monday 11th December, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Warning has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall light is forecast over the next 12 hours. We continue to monitor the situation. A Flood Alert remains in place for the wider area, and standing water and debris may still remain. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast

October and November 2023 have been exceptionally wet. Nearly a month's rainfall (75mm) has been recorded this week. Groundwater is high, close to the surface, and rising. From 13/12/2023 minor groundwater flood impacts are possible. Water could begin to appear in a small number of basements. Previous events suggest impacts may initially affect Old London Road, Patcham and Peacock Lane, Withdean. Sunday and Monday are forecast to remain mostly dry. Another 10-20mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday 12/12/2023. Groundwater could continue rising until 16/12/2023 at Ladies Mile borehole, and a few days after in Patcham. Drier weather is possible towards the end of the week. Groundwater flood impacts might ease by the last week in December. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts and liaise with Brighton and Hove City Council. We will update this message by 18:00 15/12/2023.

items.description: River Derwent at Church Wilne and Wilne Lane
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are Church Wilne, including Great Wilne, and Wilne Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid contact with flood water and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.
This message will be updated this morning, 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have now fallen following heavy rainfall yesterday and today, Sunday 10th December. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. There is no further rainfall forecast this evening or tomorrow, Monday 11th December. 

We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and clearing blockages in rivers where necessary. 

We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

River levels are high on the Lower River Eden due to recent rainfall. Flooding is affecting locations near the Lower River Eden.

Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the morning. No further flooding to fields and roads is currently expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low Barlings and the Short Ferry area

floodArea.riverOrSea: Barlings Eau, Stainfield Beck, Marsh Drain

items.message: Over the last few days there has been heavy rain over the Barlings Eau and River Witham catchment. There has been a breach on Marsh Drain which may result in localised property flooding near to Marsh Drain. River levels on the Barlings Eau and Witham remain high, but we do not currently expect widespread property flooding in the Low Barlings and Short Ferry area. Further rainfall is forecast for today, 10th November, and therefore river levels will remain high. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water.  Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council.  We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 13:00 on 11/12/23 or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Derwent at Darley Abbey, Folly Road
items.message:
River levels have risen and remained high at the Derby St Marys river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, risk of flooding to property, roads and farmland remains. Areas most at risk are access and egress to properties and businesses at Haslam’s Lane, Folly Road and Darley Mills, as Haslam's Lane becomes inundated and Darley Abbey Toll Bridge remains closed. If levels continue to rise, evacuation from the area will not be possible. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until Monday evening, 11/12/2023. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and have a bag ready with vital items like medicines and insurance documents. 
	
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: We have seen persistent rainfall in the Peterborough area which is causing River levels to rise on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 16:00 on 11/12/23, or before, if the situation changes.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: We have seen persistent rainfall in the Peterborough area which is causing river levels to rise on the River Nene. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 16:00 on 11/12/23, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
There has been heavy rainfall across the River Colne catchment over the last 48 hours. River levels are still rising at some locations in the Lower Colne catchment and they are expected to peak at around midnight tonight, Sunday 10th December. 

The main areas of concern are at Uxbridge, West Drayton, Poyle and Stanwell Moor. Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river is possible and flooding from surface water could also occur. There is no more rainfall forecast today, or tomorrow Monday 11th December so river levels are forecast to start falling throughout tomorrow and Tuesday 12th December. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are continuing to monitor river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages. 

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow morning, Monday 11th December, or sooner if the situation changes.

The Lower River Arun is high and rising at Pulborough, following Saturday's rain. In the last week, nearly a month's rainfall (80mm) has been recorded at Hardham. From 23:00 10/12/2023 water will be extensive through fields, might affect gardens and the A29, and could approach properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. The River Arun will also be high at Houghton Bridge, Amberley, but not significantly higher than it was Sunday morning. Flooding is not currently expected in Arundel. Very little rain is forecast until Tuesday. In Pulborough, the river might not begin to fall until 14:00 Monday 11/12/2023, and could be higher than normal most of the week. 10-20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday 12/12/2023, which could prolong or potentially increase the risk of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed as a precaution, in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 14:00 11/12/2023.

items.description: River Cherwell from Charwelton to just above Upper Heyford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Highfurlong Brook, Ashby Brook, Culworth Brook, Hanwell Brook, Chacombe Brook, Marston Brook, Thenford Brook, Farthinghoe Brook, Charlton Brook, River Swere, Deddington Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Cherwell as a result of a period of sustained rain. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible later this evening 10/12/2023, especially in the Banbury area. The weather forecast is for it to be mostly dry with the chance of showers this evening and overnight and Monday is forecast to be mostly dry. We expect river levels to continue rising slowly this evening and overnight. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Court Meadow, Kempsey and Callow End
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible overnight tonight, 10/12/23.  We expect flooding to affect Court Meadow Caravan Park. Predicted Peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 6.0m to 6.2m overnight tonight.   Flood water could be deep and fast flowing, and therefore pose a risk to life.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to rise until tomorrow morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and or Local Authorities.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and move possession and valuables off the ground or to safety.  
This message will be updated  by 10am on 11/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Whitewell Brook at Piercy and Newchurch from Ashworth Road to Wood Lea Road
items.message:
River levels are rising on the Whitewell Brook due to persistent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Whitewell Brook, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties adjacent to the brook.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight into Monday 11/12/2023. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on 11/12/2023, or as the situation changes.
